Class BufferPool

java.lang.Object
BufferPool
public class BufferPool extends Object
In the following basic bufferPool Class Create a simple buffer pool class that manages a fixed-size array of byte buffers. Implement methods for reading data from and writing data to the buffers. Use simple read and write operations without worrying about disk I/O or asynchronous processing. The project requirements:
Version:
2024-04-03
Author:
Emadeldin-Abdrabou-emazied

    • getBufferSize

      public int getBufferSize()
      Getter of buffer size
      Returns:
      bufferSize integer value of the buffer size, i.e., how many bytes in the buffer

    • getBufferWritingStat

      public boolean getBufferWritingStat(int buffID)
      Getter of buffer status
      Parameters:
      buffID - integer value that is used to locate the buffer ID (0-based index) of the stack element in the buffer pool to get its writing status
      Returns:
      true if buffer's dirty bit is true and false if not

    • readBytes

      public void readBytes(byte[] stuff, int byteNo, int numBytes) throws IOException
      This method handles a reading request to read a record from a file
      Parameters:
      stuff - array of bytes that would store a record that needs to be read from the file
      byteNo - integer number that refers the starting position that we need to read starting from it, i.e., position in file to start from
      numBytes - integer number that refers the amount of Bytes that are needed to be read, i.e., 4 Bytes in our case
      Throws:
      IOException

      Throws:

    • writeBytes

      public void writeBytes(byte[] stuff, int byteNo, int numBytes)
      writing to buffer (writing from quicksort) .. this writing method to be called by the quick sort class
      Parameters:
      stuff - the array of bytes that need to be written to the buffer
      byteNo - the integer number that refers to the position to start writing bytes
      numBytes - This parameter specifies the number of bytes to be written
